title: Wilson's theorem
summary: In algebra and number theory, Wilson's theorem states that a natural number n > 1 is a prime number if and only if the product of all the positive integers less than n is one less than a multiple of n.  That is (using the notations of modular arithmetic), the factorial ( n − 1 ) ! = 1 × 2 × 3 × ⋯ × ( n − 1 ) {\displaystyle (n-1)!=1\times 2\times 3\times \cdots \times (n-1)} satisfies
